description:
This Accelerated Cisco CCNA Routing + Switching show helps candidate review their exam readiness for 200-105 exam.  It’s a fast paced and hard hitting review of every exam objective for latest CCNA 200-105 exam. The accelerated pace is helpful for those that are ready for the exam and give an in-depth review of each objective you may encounter for CCNA R+S.
The episodes can be used as part of building a candidate's knowledge and skills in LAN switching technologies such as trunking, VLAN trunking protocol and dealing with Switching loops along with troubleshooting. IPv4 and IPv6 routing technologies in RIPng, EIGRP and OSPF are also discussed and configured helping the candidate to understand and troubleshoot configuration and routing issues. WAN technologies, infrastructure services, and infrastructure maintenance technologies are also described and configured to help the CCNA candidate not only for the exam but also for business and production use.
name: Accelerated CCNA Routing and Switching
subtitle: Cisco Certified Network Associate

episodes.description: This show helps the Cisco CCNA Routing + Switching candidate prepare for the 200-105 exam objectives. The episodes can be used as part of building a candidate's knowledge and skills in LAN switching technologies such as trunking, VLAN trunking protocol and dealing with Switching loops along with troubleshooting. IPv4 and IPv6 routing technologies in RIPng, EIGRP and OSPF are also discussed and configured helping the candidate to understand and troubleshoot configuration and routing issues. WAN technologies, infrastructure services, and infrastructure maintenance technologies are also described and configured to help the CCNA candidate not only for the exam but also for business and production use.
episodes.title: Introduction to ICND2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.055 --> 00:00:09.411
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:09.411 --> 00:00:11.190
Welcome to ITProTV.

3
00:00:11.190 --> 00:00:15.992
Today, we're gonna introduce you to
the new ICND2 content, getting ready for

4
00:00:15.992 --> 00:00:20.167
that CCNA routing and
switching exam, Exam number 200-105.

5
00:00:20.167 --> 00:00:23.372
And here to give us some details
on it is gonna be Mr. Todd Lammle.

6
00:00:23.372 --> 00:00:24.141
Thank you for joining us.

7
00:00:24.141 --> 00:00:26.151
>> All right, Ronnie,
it's great to be here and be back.

8
00:00:26.151 --> 00:00:29.072
We're gonna jump into ICND2.

9
00:00:29.072 --> 00:00:33.190
Hopefully you've gone though ICND1 and
CCENT, and maybe even took your exam and

10
00:00:33.190 --> 00:00:34.511
that's under your belt.

11
00:00:34.511 --> 00:00:37.996
Or you're looking to build some more
foundation before you take your CCENT,

12
00:00:37.996 --> 00:00:39.410
that's a good idea.

13
00:00:39.410 --> 00:00:42.320
All right, so in these episodes
we're going to go ahead and

14
00:00:42.320 --> 00:00:45.350
start with deep understanding
of switching, all right?

15
00:00:45.350 --> 00:00:48.400
We're gonna do enhanced switching,
and that includes

16
00:00:48.400 --> 00:00:52.580
a deep dive into spanning tree protocol
and rapid spanning tree protocol.

17
00:00:52.580 --> 00:00:56.620
Also, back on the objectives
from at least six years ago

18
00:00:56.620 --> 00:01:00.014
on the CCNA is something
called virtual trunk protocol.

19
00:01:00.014 --> 00:01:04.740
So it's back, right, and we're gonna
go through VTP and learn how to use

20
00:01:04.740 --> 00:01:09.400
that in CDP to find your bridge and to
update your databases and stuff like that.

21
00:01:09.400 --> 00:01:12.550
And then we're going to go ahead and have
some fun after we get through all those

22
00:01:12.550 --> 00:01:15.850
episodes, and hit something ether
channel where we're bundling things.

23
00:01:15.850 --> 00:01:19.009
So we're not using spanning tree, really,
or we're gonna bundle our links so

24
00:01:19.009 --> 00:01:20.850
spanning tree sees it as one link.

25
00:01:20.850 --> 00:01:25.209
And then we're gonna hit HSRP, which
is somewhat of a disappointment to me,

26
00:01:25.209 --> 00:01:29.314
because we really shouldn't use HSRP
today, you should be using GLBP.

27
00:01:29.314 --> 00:01:32.578
But in the new objectives
they came out with in 2016,

28
00:01:32.578 --> 00:01:36.185
they took that off when it was on before,
and only left on HSRP.

29
00:01:36.185 --> 00:01:38.700
And that's a mistake as far as I can tell.

30
00:01:38.700 --> 00:01:42.333
But, we're gonna go through HSRP
in detail, we're gonna use it,

31
00:01:42.333 --> 00:01:46.364
you're gonna pass your CCNA and
then never use HSRP again, only use GLBP.

32
00:01:46.364 --> 00:01:48.357
All right, and we'll talk about that.

33
00:01:48.357 --> 00:01:52.743
All right, then we're gonna hit
a deep dive into EIGRP and EIGRPv6.

34
00:01:52.743 --> 00:01:54.946
We're gonna spend a good
amount of time on that,

35
00:01:54.946 --> 00:01:58.975
really understanding it's a routing
protocol that just always seems to work.

36
00:01:58.975 --> 00:02:02.593
And unlike the next episode after that,
OSPF E2 and OSPF E3,

37
00:02:02.593 --> 00:02:07.165
it's a little more convoluted and we have
a little bit more work to do with OSPF,

38
00:02:07.165 --> 00:02:10.119
and a little bit more
fundamental understanding.

39
00:02:10.119 --> 00:02:13.855
So it is a much bigger section than
it is on EIGRP cuz there's just so

40
00:02:13.855 --> 00:02:14.803
much more to it.

41
00:02:14.803 --> 00:02:16.961
All right, so after that we're
gonna hit troubleshooting.

42
00:02:16.961 --> 00:02:22.375
I'm gonna go back to all our routing
protocols, and default routes.

43
00:02:22.375 --> 00:02:26.660
And we're going to look at IP and
IPv6 access lists,

44
00:02:26.660 --> 00:02:29.719
both standard and extended, right?

45
00:02:29.719 --> 00:02:33.564
So, in the CCENT only covered
standard access lists, but

46
00:02:33.564 --> 00:02:38.960
now they don't get real big into extended
access lists in the CCNA anymore.

47
00:02:38.960 --> 00:02:41.710
But in the troubleshooting section,
we're gonna have to understand

48
00:02:41.710 --> 00:02:45.350
extended access lists and
be able to troubleshoot both IP 4 and

49
00:02:45.350 --> 00:02:48.350
IP version 6 and
that's kinda a new objective there.

50
00:02:48.350 --> 00:02:52.070
Then, we're gonna go and hit, in the
troubleshooting section, we've got SPAN

51
00:02:52.070 --> 00:02:55.690
and we've got service level agreements
that we're gonna use to troubleshoot and

52
00:02:55.690 --> 00:02:57.360
test our networks with, okay?

53
00:02:57.360 --> 00:03:00.070
So then after that we're
gonna hit wide area networks.

54
00:03:00.070 --> 00:03:03.290
Now, the good news is,
after all of these years,

55
00:03:03.290 --> 00:03:07.260
Frame Relay is no longer on a CCNA,
that is so long overdue.

56
00:03:07.260 --> 00:03:12.860
So starting in 2016 they took out the
Frame Relay and we've got more PPP really.

57
00:03:12.860 --> 00:03:15.470
So we still have some serial links, right?

58
00:03:15.470 --> 00:03:18.270
I don't see those a lot in any of
my customers too much anymore.

59
00:03:18.270 --> 00:03:20.230
But if you have serial links,
you can still run HTLC,

60
00:03:20.230 --> 00:03:23.080
that's still in the objectives,
but PPP, multi-link PPP.

61
00:03:23.080 --> 00:03:25.590
And then we're gonna go ahead and
hit our tunnels,

62
00:03:25.590 --> 00:03:28.540
we'll top out VPN, build a GRE tunnel.

63
00:03:28.540 --> 00:03:34.020
And then we're gonna end with a really
fun lab on BGP, border gateway protocols.

64
00:03:34.020 --> 00:03:35.850
So that's a new objective as well.

65
00:03:35.850 --> 00:03:38.650
And then we're gonna end with
network device security and

66
00:03:38.650 --> 00:03:41.230
evolution of intelligent networks.

67
00:03:41.230 --> 00:03:43.030
Those will be our last episodes.

68
00:03:43.030 --> 00:03:46.312
They're not nearly as long, so we start
off with really long episodes, right?

69
00:03:46.312 --> 00:03:49.658
We kinda then have some fun,
get into EIGRP,

70
00:03:49.658 --> 00:03:54.780
get into some real heavy depth in OSPF and
troubleshooting, right?

71
00:03:54.780 --> 00:03:57.888
And then we end up with
some fun new stuff, right?

72
00:03:57.888 --> 00:04:01.377
That's how the new ICND2 is gonna go,
so stick around.

73
00:04:01.377 --> 00:04:04.740
Let's head, right now,
into enhanced switching.

74
00:04:04.740 --> 00:04:11.507
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd Lammle describes and configures how a CCNA candidate deals with switch loop problems such as broadcast storms, multiple source paths and mac-address table instabilities.  He demonstrates how STP, Spanning-Tree Protocol, works to stop these problems by creating a single path for data to the Root Bridge.  He describes the STP Root Bridge Selection and how non-root bridges decides it’s root port as well as how to decide whether ports block or forward data.   Todd also introduces the different STP standards of 802.1d, 802.1w, and 802.1s.
episodes.title: Enhanced Switching
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.385 --> 00:00:15.506
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.506 --> 00:00:19.813
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and today,
we're going into our CCNA Routing and

4
00:00:19.813 --> 00:00:21.570
Switching Content.

5
00:00:21.570 --> 00:00:24.834
We're getting ready for this brand new
exam and in our studios today that's

6
00:00:24.834 --> 00:00:28.054
gonna help us along to make sure that
we're focused in on what we need to be.

7
00:00:28.054 --> 00:00:30.863
Mr. Todd Lammle, thank you for
joining us in our studio.

8
00:00:30.863 --> 00:00:32.740
>> Thank you, Ronnie,
it's good to be here.

9
00:00:32.740 --> 00:00:35.625
Let's dive right into the ICND2
objective for enhanced switching.

10
00:00:35.625 --> 00:00:40.043
That's gonna be spanning tree,
EtherChannel and a couple other things,

11
00:00:40.043 --> 00:00:43.960
port fast, we're gonna get
through some of those things.

12
00:00:43.960 --> 00:00:46.430
So let's dive into the objectives.

13
00:00:46.430 --> 00:00:49.192
This is a huge objective for
ICND2, no doubt about it.

14
00:00:49.192 --> 00:00:54.120
So [COUGH] one of the other things that
they have in the objectives is a review

15
00:00:54.120 --> 00:00:57.910
of just basic VLANs and trunks and
access links and voice links.

16
00:00:57.910 --> 00:01:01.210
And so although I'm not gonna review
them here because we covered them and

17
00:01:01.210 --> 00:01:03.220
you have an option to go back to them.

18
00:01:03.220 --> 00:01:06.068
Just understand they are part of
the objectives, so let's go ahead and

19
00:01:06.068 --> 00:01:07.735
dive right into spanning tree right now.

20
00:01:10.263 --> 00:01:12.522
First off we want a redundant connection,

21
00:01:12.522 --> 00:01:14.980
we want multiple
connections between links.

22
00:01:14.980 --> 00:01:17.180
And when we get to our next episode,

23
00:01:17.180 --> 00:01:20.150
we'll get to our next section
of enhanced switching.

24
00:01:20.150 --> 00:01:23.139
We'll see that we're gonna talk about
EtherChannel where we're connecting

25
00:01:23.139 --> 00:01:25.230
multiple links together between switches.

26
00:01:25.230 --> 00:01:29.060
So right now we love spanning tree,
we have multiple links and

27
00:01:29.060 --> 00:01:35.210
if we didn't have spanning tree to shut
down extra ports, we'd have a loop, right?

28
00:01:35.210 --> 00:01:39.110
So if we don't implement this correctly,
we're gonna have a loop at layer two.

29
00:01:39.110 --> 00:01:42.470
Now the problem with the loop at layer
two is your network still works,

30
00:01:42.470 --> 00:01:46.290
just albeit very slowly and it's
extremely difficult to find this problem.

31
00:01:46.290 --> 00:01:49.470
That's why this is a death sentence
if you get a loop at layer two.

32
00:01:50.610 --> 00:01:54.040
So it's pretty funny, it's like we love
spanning tree, we get the EtherChannel up.

33
00:01:54.040 --> 00:01:57.120
We hate spanning-tree, right,
it's like I want all my links up.

34
00:01:57.120 --> 00:02:00.440
All right, so we're gonna be
a little different here anyways.

35
00:02:00.440 --> 00:02:03.080
So we wanna eliminate
single points of failures.

36
00:02:03.080 --> 00:02:06.670
But let's take a look down here,
you can't see this.

37
00:02:06.670 --> 00:02:11.920
Broadcast storms, multiple frame copies,
MAC address instability problems.

38
00:02:11.920 --> 00:02:14.880
Because we don't know where the MAC
address is coming in on multiple ports.

39
00:02:14.880 --> 00:02:18.170
This is all what happens if we don't
implement a redundant topology correctly.

40
00:02:18.170 --> 00:02:22.806
So what we're going to do,
by default, the spanning

41
00:02:22.806 --> 00:02:28.340
tree creates a blocked port and
network is just simple like this.

42
00:02:28.340 --> 00:02:30.080
So it stops us from having a loop.

43
00:02:30.080 --> 00:02:34.250
Now this happens on all IOS
switches by default, okay?

44
00:02:34.250 --> 00:02:40.190
We run a certain kind 802.1d,
they came out in 1977, all right.

45
00:02:40.190 --> 00:02:42.170
So we're running the same version.

46
00:02:42.170 --> 00:02:47.710
Now Cisco runs an enhanced version we'll
talk about, it's called PVST+ right here,

47
00:02:47.710 --> 00:02:50.120
Per VLAN Spanning Tree.

48
00:02:50.120 --> 00:02:55.070
And we'll talk about why they do this and
how this enhances it and it really does.

49
00:02:55.070 --> 00:02:57.550
So we take the original one and

50
00:02:57.550 --> 00:03:03.240
make it proprietary by having an enhanced
protocol on top of it, PVST+, all right?

51
00:03:03.240 --> 00:03:08.450
So by doing this, having this STP,
loop-free redundant network topology,

52
00:03:08.450 --> 00:03:11.350
we place certain ports
in the blocking state.

53
00:03:11.350 --> 00:03:13.810
Which stop us from,
we will no longer have a loop, so

54
00:03:13.810 --> 00:03:17.750
if it comes here, then it won't come
out here, it will only go out this way.

55
00:03:17.750 --> 00:03:22.660
We have to have only one port per
designated segment forwarding.

56
00:03:22.660 --> 00:03:25.280
If we have both, then we'll end
up with a loop here, all right.

57
00:03:26.330 --> 00:03:33.580
So we have the original one and this is
why we use the term bridge now today.

58
00:03:33.580 --> 00:03:36.500
So when we talk about spanning tree,
I'm not gonna use the term switching.

59
00:03:36.500 --> 00:03:38.544
Cisco's not gonna use the term
switching when they get into this,

60
00:03:38.544 --> 00:03:40.180
better say the term bridges.

61
00:03:40.180 --> 00:03:41.950
Because that's all we had
when this came out and

62
00:03:41.950 --> 00:03:45.010
when we're talking about spanning tree,
we're referring to bridges.

63
00:03:46.330 --> 00:03:48.368
Switches are multiport bridges, right?

64
00:03:48.368 --> 00:03:52.132
Now the spanning-tree root port selection,
so

65
00:03:52.132 --> 00:03:57.530
basically we have to determine
who's the king of our network.

66
00:03:57.530 --> 00:04:02.210
Who's the king of and well the way Cisco
looks at it Per VLAN Spanning Tree,

67
00:04:02.210 --> 00:04:05.080
who's the king of our VLAN, all right?

68
00:04:05.080 --> 00:04:09.190
And so all roads lead to Rome in
the sense that we have the king in Rome,

69
00:04:09.190 --> 00:04:10.980
that's our root bridge.

70
00:04:10.980 --> 00:04:15.630
And every other switch must make
a single path to that root bridge.

71
00:04:15.630 --> 00:04:18.660
Every other bridge must make
a single path to that root bridge.

72
00:04:18.660 --> 00:04:22.130
All other ports are either designated or
shut down, okay?

73
00:04:22.130 --> 00:04:24.712
Or disabled, now so let's go ahead and
take a look at this.

74
00:04:24.712 --> 00:04:28.610
So I have switch X here and switch Y and

75
00:04:28.610 --> 00:04:33.268
what we wanna do is look at what's
called the bridge ID, bridge ID.

76
00:04:33.268 --> 00:04:36.087
Now this comprises of
a bridge priority and

77
00:04:36.087 --> 00:04:38.836
by the way, so we can see this right here.

78
00:04:38.836 --> 00:04:42.482
32768 is a, you can expand this out,

79
00:04:42.482 --> 00:04:47.548
32768 is a default, so
it's 0 through 65535,

80
00:04:47.548 --> 00:04:52.850
so we're kind of right in
the middle there, aren't we?

81
00:04:52.850 --> 00:04:56.390
That's the default on all
Cisco IOS switches, right?

82
00:04:56.390 --> 00:04:57.480
So they're all the same.

83
00:04:57.480 --> 00:05:01.390
So when they're the same,
now we're gonna use the MAC address, so

84
00:05:01.390 --> 00:05:03.100
we combine these two.

85
00:05:03.100 --> 00:05:09.570
Whoever has the lowest MAC address,
lowest priority becomes your root bridge.

86
00:05:09.570 --> 00:05:13.360
So in this case here, we've both
have the same priority and then but

87
00:05:13.360 --> 00:05:16.840
we have look it here 1111 and 2222, right?

88
00:05:16.840 --> 00:05:19.840
That's not reality, but
in this case that's how we do it, so

89
00:05:19.840 --> 00:05:23.260
this guy is gonna become
what's called my root bridge.

90
00:05:24.820 --> 00:05:28.080
All ports on the root bridge
are forwarding and can never be blocked or

91
00:05:28.080 --> 00:05:29.490
discarded nothing, right?

92
00:05:29.490 --> 00:05:30.323
So they're all forwarding.

93
00:05:30.323 --> 00:05:35.569
Now, we come over here to what's
referred to as the non-root bridge and

94
00:05:35.569 --> 00:05:39.320
we have to make a single
path to the root bridge.

95
00:05:39.320 --> 00:05:43.590
Now on this drawing here I can't
really tell if this was a one gig and

96
00:05:43.590 --> 00:05:47.690
this was a fast ethernet,
then we choose this port.

97
00:05:47.690 --> 00:05:51.190
This would be my what's
called a root port.

98
00:05:51.190 --> 00:05:55.490
Now remember a root port is
not the same as a root bridge.

99
00:05:55.490 --> 00:05:57.490
Route bridges can't have root ports.

100
00:05:57.490 --> 00:06:02.180
Route port is my single
path to the root bridge.

101
00:06:02.180 --> 00:06:04.669
This other port would go into blocking.

102
00:06:06.431 --> 00:06:09.916
Okay, so let's go ahead and

103
00:06:09.916 --> 00:06:15.590
take a look at a couple
of other examples here.

104
00:06:15.590 --> 00:06:18.772
One root bridge per broadcast domain,
one root bridge per broadcast domain.

105
00:06:18.772 --> 00:06:21.810
So this is what, I just want to
go ahead and explain all these.

106
00:06:21.810 --> 00:06:29.190
Per VLAN Spanning Tree+, so for
every VLAN, I'm going to have a king.

107
00:06:29.190 --> 00:06:30.670
A root bridge.

108
00:06:30.670 --> 00:06:36.600
And every other bridge in that VLAN must
make a single path to the root bridge.

109
00:06:36.600 --> 00:06:39.990
So my switch might be the king for

110
00:06:39.990 --> 00:06:43.500
multiple VLANs or one and
another switch could be I want it.

111
00:06:43.500 --> 00:06:48.060
It helps us have efficiency and I'll
show you this in our drawing in a bit.

112
00:06:48.060 --> 00:06:49.830
Okay, that's not the most
important thing right now.

113
00:06:49.830 --> 00:06:52.690
We'll determine how that
becomes efficient in a minute.

114
00:06:52.690 --> 00:06:56.270
But anyways, we need to understand
that we have only one root bridge.

115
00:06:56.270 --> 00:07:00.060
All other bridges in that VLAN,
ie broadcast domain.

116
00:07:00.060 --> 00:07:02.309
VLAN equals broadcast domain
equals the subnet, right?

117
00:07:04.240 --> 00:07:08.390
All must make a single
path to that root bridge.

118
00:07:08.390 --> 00:07:11.750
That single path,
that port that they use is called a what?

119
00:07:11.750 --> 00:07:12.550
Root port.

120
00:07:13.670 --> 00:07:16.313
So if I saw an output and
it showed a root port,

121
00:07:16.313 --> 00:07:19.179
I would know that was a non-root bridge,
okay?

122
00:07:19.179 --> 00:07:26.130
Now all other switches in that broadcast
domain, ie subnet, ie VLAN, same thing.

123
00:07:26.130 --> 00:07:30.560
We'll have only one root port,
that's how we have a single path.

124
00:07:30.560 --> 00:07:32.698
One root port per non-root bridge.

125
00:07:32.698 --> 00:07:36.290
Now again, same thing, only one root port.

126
00:07:36.290 --> 00:07:37.970
One designated port per segment.

127
00:07:37.970 --> 00:07:41.260
So on this case here,
let's take a look down here and

128
00:07:41.260 --> 00:07:43.450
see this guy's the root bridge.

129
00:07:43.450 --> 00:07:47.167
And then this guy's the non-root
bridge based on the bridge ID, okay?

130
00:07:47.167 --> 00:07:51.659
So these are all gonna be, these
are referred to as designated, whoops,

131
00:07:51.659 --> 00:07:55.582
designated forwarding ports,

00:43:28.878 --> 00:43:30.260
This would say more, right?

825
00:43:30.260 --> 00:43:32.305
And then you spacebar and
you get your next VLAN.

826
00:43:32.305 --> 00:43:35.358
But let's take a look at this and
how you can find your root bridge.

827
00:43:35.358 --> 00:43:38.245
All right, so the top part here,
first off it tells me,

828
00:43:38.245 --> 00:43:42.116
notice I just type show spanning-tree
cuz that's the command I would type

829
00:43:42.116 --> 00:43:44.529
to find out information
about my root bridge.

830
00:43:44.529 --> 00:43:47.111
Show spanning-tree, right here.

831
00:43:47.111 --> 00:43:49.664
This ieee is 802.1d.

832
00:43:52.439 --> 00:43:58.123
Root bridge priority, 32769, let's talk
about that because the default is 32768.

833
00:43:58.123 --> 00:44:03.150
Now right here, this tells us,
this bridge is the root, right?

834
00:44:03.150 --> 00:44:06.850
So it's pretty fun when you turn on

835
00:44:06.850 --> 00:44:08.650
it comes up and says, I am the root.

836
00:44:08.650 --> 00:44:10.700
It actually transmits that out.

837
00:44:10.700 --> 00:44:14.200
So this is information
about the root bridge here.

838
00:44:14.200 --> 00:44:17.671
This is information about
the root bridge for VLAN 1.

839
00:44:17.671 --> 00:44:19.766
That's this guy right here.

840
00:44:19.766 --> 00:44:20.559
That's the root bridge.

841
00:44:20.559 --> 00:44:24.330
Now in this case here, the information
down here, the bridge ID and

842
00:44:24.330 --> 00:44:26.127
so on is exactly the same, why?

843
00:44:26.127 --> 00:44:27.900
Because I am the root bridge.

844
00:44:27.900 --> 00:44:29.618
The other way I can tell I'm
the root bridge is down here.

845
00:44:29.618 --> 00:44:32.792
Notice that everything is
designated forwarding?

846
00:44:32.792 --> 00:44:34.829
Designated forwarding.

847
00:44:34.829 --> 00:44:39.824
Now, I can have all forwarding ports or
designated ports on a non-root bridge,

848
00:44:39.824 --> 00:44:43.672
but I'm gonna have something in there,
a non-root bridge.

849
00:44:43.672 --> 00:44:48.040
I'm gonna have a root port,
a root port, right?

850
00:44:48.040 --> 00:44:50.850
So in this case here,
I don't even have a root port, all right?

851
00:44:50.850 --> 00:44:54.470
So I have here,
notice that I have cost of 100, so

852
00:44:54.470 --> 00:44:59.230
this is a 10 megabit port, these are fast

853
00:44:59.230 --> 00:45:04.690
Notice I had plugged these into a hub and

854
00:45:04.690 --> 00:45:07.550
And this is a point-to-point connection.

855
00:45:07.550 --> 00:45:10.600
All right, so
I can tell I'm in root bridge

856
00:45:10.600 --> 00:45:12.930
because everything's designated
forwarding, but hold on again.

857
00:45:12.930 --> 00:45:15.750
A non-root bridge can have
everything forwarding, but

858
00:45:15.750 --> 00:45:20.770
you would have a root port that says

859
00:45:20.770 --> 00:45:22.040
I don't have that here.

860
00:45:22.040 --> 00:45:24.920
And it also says that I'm the root bridge,

861
00:45:24.920 --> 00:45:29.110
So just because you don't see any block

862
00:45:29.110 --> 00:45:31.450
If you don't have a root port,
then you're root bridge.

863
00:45:31.450 --> 00:45:33.215
Just like this says,
I'm definitely the root bridge.

864
00:45:33.215 --> 00:45:38.297
Show spanning-tree, VLAN1, 802.1d.

865
00:45:38.297 --> 00:45:39.470
Let me mention this.

00:45:39.470 --> 00:45:40.638
So notice the priority.

867
00:45:40.638 --> 00:45:43.493
I just wrote over it, 32769.

868
00:45:47.630 --> 00:45:49.836
32769, okay?

869
00:45:49.836 --> 00:45:52.290
What about,
I thought my priority was 32768.

870
00:45:52.290 --> 00:45:57.671
It is, Cisco uses something
called a system ID extension.

871
00:45:57.671 --> 00:46:01.472
So what it does is it
takes the root bridge ID,

872
00:46:01.472 --> 00:46:06.586
the priority here, 32768,
and adds the VLAN number.

873
00:46:06.586 --> 00:46:09.822
So for VLAN1, it's 327.

874
00:46:09.822 --> 00:46:12.331
So my priority right here is 32768.

875
00:46:12.331 --> 00:46:14.777
Add the VLAN number, it's 32769.

876
00:46:14.777 --> 00:46:21.526
For VLAN2, it'd be 32770,
VLAN3, 32771, and so on.

877
00:46:21.526 --> 00:46:24.063
So it uses something called
a system ID extension,

878
00:46:24.063 --> 00:46:26.240
that's why they're not the same.

879
00:46:26.240 --> 00:46:31.564
Now I can see up here this is
the information about the root bridge for

880
00:46:31.564 --> 00:46:33.400
VLAN1.

881
00:46:33.400 --> 00:46:34.450
That's where I'm at.

882
00:46:34.450 --> 00:46:37.802
Remember I could have typed show

883
00:46:37.802 --> 00:46:40.716
Or down here, press spacebar and
get to the next VLAN.

884
00:46:40.716 --> 00:46:44.750
But nonetheless,
notice this is not my root bridge.

885
00:46:44.750 --> 00:46:46.770
How do you find your root bridge?

886
00:46:46.770 --> 00:46:49.250
Show spanning-tree.

887
00:46:49.250 --> 00:46:50.190
Now this is gonna tell me.

888
00:46:50.190 --> 00:46:51.430
Look at this.

889
00:46:51.430 --> 00:46:53.570
Here's the Mac address of the root bridge.

890
00:46:53.570 --> 00:46:55.000
Here's my root bridge.

891
00:46:55.000 --> 00:46:56.400
Well, that doesn't really help me.

892
00:46:56.400 --> 00:46:57.320
I gotta be honest with you.

893
00:46:57.320 --> 00:46:59.718
You give me a Mac address of the root
bridge, it doesn't do much for me.

894
00:46:59.718 --> 00:47:03.688
But in this case here it's saying,
but you're a cost of 19 away.

895
00:47:03.688 --> 00:47:05.340
What does that mean?

896
00:47:05.340 --> 00:47:09.160
Well, that means one,
one fast ethernet link away.

897
00:47:09.160 --> 00:47:15.370
And it tells you right here, your root
bridge is connected off of Port 1.

898
00:47:15.370 --> 00:47:16.860
I can come down here and see that.

899
00:47:16.860 --> 00:47:20.110
My root port, so
if I didn't have a blocking port here.

900
00:47:20.110 --> 00:47:24.530
I would still know I'm a non-root
bridge because I have a root port.

901
00:47:24.530 --> 00:47:26.636
Root ports say,
here's how I get to my root bridge.

902
00:47:26.636 --> 00:47:28.573
It's off of Fa0/1.

903
00:47:28.573 --> 00:47:32.487
Now, I wouldn't know to look at this,
where my root bridge is, but

904
00:47:32.487 --> 00:47:34.009
it says your cost of 19.

905
00:47:34.009 --> 00:47:38.293
If it said a cost of 38, that means I'm
two bridges away from the root bridge.

906
00:47:38.293 --> 00:47:42.923
I am directly connected to
the root bridge, off of Fa0/1.

907
00:47:42.923 --> 00:47:46.620
So in this example, again guys,
pay attention to what I'm saying here.

908
00:47:46.620 --> 00:47:48.590
How do you find your root bridge?

909
00:47:48.590 --> 00:47:51.054
You're gonna have to type out,
show spanning-tree, and

910
00:47:51.054 --> 00:47:54.322
you're gonna have to type out probably
the VLAN number, it doesn't matter.

911
00:47:54.322 --> 00:48:00.053
Find your root port, trace that,
you might have to use show CDP.

912
00:48:00.053 --> 00:48:02.253
Whatever.
Trace that to your root bridge,

913
00:48:02.253 --> 00:48:06.497
it's critical for your exam objectives
that you can find your root bridge for

914
00:48:06.497 --> 00:48:07.990
our VLAN, all right.

915
00:48:07.990 --> 00:48:10.090
So we can see that we have an alternate,
right?

916
00:48:10.090 --> 00:48:12.360
This is my backup, my blocked board here.

917
00:48:13.370 --> 00:48:14.775
And this is information about me.

918
00:48:14.775 --> 00:48:18.070
All right here's my Mac address and so on.

919
00:48:18.070 --> 00:48:19.830
So, no that's how I find my root bridge.

920
00:48:19.830 --> 00:48:21.810
Show span entry, follow your root port.

921
00:48:21.810 --> 00:48:29.140
I might have to use CDP, and find out
who my neighbor is, go into that switch,

922
00:48:29.140 --> 00:48:34.620
find and show the spanning-tree to find
out who the root port is, if I'm too away.

923
00:48:34.620 --> 00:48:38.440
No in this one here,
show spanning-tree vlan 30.

924
00:48:38.440 --> 00:48:40.616
Show spanning-tree vlan 30.

925
00:48:40.616 --> 00:48:46.080
All right so now I'm looking at vlan 30,
I'm not looking at the vlan 1 first,

926
00:48:46.080 --> 00:48:49.420
because if I just type show
spanning-tree vlan 1 would show up.

927
00:48:49.420 --> 00:48:52.340
But in this case here,
I'm looking directly at vlan 30.

928
00:48:52.340 --> 00:48:54.500
Let's take a look at it..

929
00:48:54.500 --> 00:48:57.035
First off, notice what i'm running.

930
00:48:57.035 --> 00:49:01.720
RSTP 802.1, 802.1W right?

931
00:49:01.720 --> 00:49:03.066
802.1W.

932
00:49:03.066 --> 00:49:08.440
So not 802.1D, rapid span entry protocol.

933
00:49:08.440 --> 00:49:10.290
Now this priority is what?

934
00:49:10.290 --> 00:49:11.750
Well, I'm gonna look at that.

935
00:49:11.750 --> 00:49:13.090
The priorities didn't change.

936
00:49:13.090 --> 00:49:14.760
How I get my root ports didn't change?

937
00:49:14.760 --> 00:49:16.460
How I get my root bridge didn't change?

938
00:49:16.460 --> 00:49:18.470
Don't get confused with
Rapid Spanning Tree Protocol.

939
00:49:18.470 --> 00:49:20.320
All it did was converge faster.

940
00:49:20.320 --> 00:49:23.030
My bridge parity here is what?

941
00:49:23.030 --> 00:49:26.250
Lower than the default, that's your
answer for the exam objectives.

942
00:49:26.250 --> 00:49:27.500
What do you know about this bridge parity?

943
00:49:27.500 --> 00:49:29.090
It's lower than the default, right?

944
00:49:29.090 --> 00:49:30.410
That's all there is to it, okay?

945
00:49:30.410 --> 00:49:34.690
So that's gonna make
this bridge the route.

946
00:49:34.690 --> 00:49:36.800
Because the bridge ID was
lower than the default.

947
00:49:36.800 --> 00:49:39.430
All right now if I look down here,
the other way I can tell,

948
00:49:39.430 --> 00:49:44.130
I have designated forwarding ports here,
designated forwarding ports.

949
00:49:44.130 --> 00:49:47.430
I don't have any root ports or
blocked ports.

950
00:49:47.430 --> 00:49:49.310
All right so we're root port, root bridge,

951
00:49:49.310 --> 00:49:51.469
we can tell,
cuz all ports are in a forwarding state.

952
00:49:53.050 --> 00:49:56.750
They, now, one of the things if someone
says hey what's true about this?

953
00:49:56.750 --> 00:50:00.040
One of your options would be well the
states are blocking forwarding listing,

954
00:50:00.040 --> 00:50:03.930
that's not true it's RSTP you
can't have a blocking port.

955
00:50:03.930 --> 00:50:08.380
You have discarding,
discarding learning forwarding, okay and

956
00:50:08.380 --> 00:50:10.190
we know that the bridge priority is lower.

957
00:50:10.190 --> 00:50:13.340
Now let's take a look at one
more technology that's new for

958
00:50:13.340 --> 00:50:15.700
the objectives now, it wasn't.

959
00:50:15.700 --> 00:50:18.310
It was not in the last objectives.

960
00:50:18.310 --> 00:50:20.400
It's now new in these new objectives.

961
00:50:23.140 --> 00:50:23.720
Okay?

962
00:50:23.720 --> 00:50:27.450
And that's VLAN Trunking Protocol or VTP.

963
00:50:29.320 --> 00:50:33.855
VLAN Trunking Protocol, okay so
years ago this was on the CCNA, it's back.

964
00:50:33.855 --> 00:50:38.000
[LAUGH]
It's convoluted,

965
00:50:38.000 --> 00:50:39.500
there is no doubt about it.

966
00:50:39.500 --> 00:50:42.560
I didn't see a huge amount of objectives
on this, but we're going to go through it.

967
00:50:42.560 --> 00:50:43.130
Alright?

968
00:50:43.130 --> 00:50:44.870
So just a couple more slides guys.

969
00:50:44.870 --> 00:50:47.030
I know this has been a huge section.

970
00:50:47.030 --> 00:50:48.050
Hang in there.

971
00:50:48.050 --> 00:50:51.320
So the first thing you do is
you set what's called a domain.

972
00:50:51.320 --> 00:50:53.690
Right?
And by default, everyone's a,

973
00:50:53.690 --> 00:50:55.240
what's called a VTP server.

974
00:50:55.240 --> 00:50:56.300
So let's talk about this.

975
00:50:57.680 --> 00:51:03.590
Now, the idea of VTP is that I
create my VLAN database, right?

976
00:51:03.590 --> 00:51:05.740
And then on one switch.

977
00:51:05.740 --> 00:51:08.970
Now, I usually have to go to every
other switch and configure those.

978
00:51:08.970 --> 00:51:10.330
But you could make something wrong.

979
00:51:10.330 --> 00:51:13.120
So if other words I came up here and
said VLAN 2 named sales, and

980
00:51:13.120 --> 00:51:15.760
then I came down here and
said VLAN2 name finance.

981
00:51:15.760 --> 00:51:17.130
I might get confused.

982
00:51:17.130 --> 00:51:19.300
My naming isn't consistent.

983
00:51:19.300 --> 00:51:22.505
So this helps naming stay
consistent across your switches.

984
00:51:24.140 --> 00:51:25.600
Most people don't use this anymore, and

985
00:51:25.600 --> 00:51:27.470
I think that's why Cisco
had taken it off the exam.

986
00:51:27.470 --> 00:51:29.620
I'm not even sure why it's back.

987
00:51:29.620 --> 00:51:34.500
Anyways, so if I'm a VTP server, and
all of them are VTP servers by default.

988
00:51:34.500 --> 00:51:38.246
I can create, add and

989
00:51:38.246 --> 00:51:43.260
delete VLANs.

990
00:51:43.260 --> 00:51:45.480
Okay, that's, you're like, yeah, so
I can't do that on all switches?

991
00:51:45.480 --> 00:51:47.260
No, no you can't.

992
00:51:47.260 --> 00:51:49.070
Only on servers, all right?

993
00:51:49.070 --> 00:51:51.490
Now, these guys, notice, are clients.

994
00:51:51.490 --> 00:51:54.290
Now I have to go and
configure them as clients.

995
00:51:54.290 --> 00:51:56.180
Remember all of them
are servers by default.

996
00:51:56.180 --> 00:51:57.580
So it means I can create add and

997
00:51:57.580 --> 00:52:01.770
delete vlans on every switch coming off
the Cisco factory floor by default.

998
00:52:02.820 --> 00:52:07.470
So now I'm gonna come up here and
I'm gonna say create a v to p domain name.

999
00:52:07.470 --> 00:52:10.110
The minimum I have to do is connect
these guys with trunk links,

1000
00:52:10.110 --> 00:52:14.440
create a domain name and then create some
VLANs and it will be propagated out.

1001
00:52:14.440 --> 00:52:15.780
Now these guys can be servers and

1002
00:52:15.780 --> 00:52:20.160
still receive that, that's based on
something called my revision number.

1003
00:52:22.170 --> 00:52:27.070
So my revision number says I have
a higher better VLAN database than

1004
00:52:27.070 --> 00:52:31.889
you delete yours, that was the key point
right there, delete yours and insert mine.

1005
00:52:32.980 --> 00:52:33.890
So it doesn't add it.

1006
00:52:33.890 --> 00:52:36.860
It actually deletes their VLAN database.

1007
00:52:36.860 --> 00:52:40.440
So that was been a point of
contention of VTP for a long time.

1008
00:52:40.440 --> 00:52:44.320
Anyways VTP service create and
delete, clients receive it.

1009
00:52:44.320 --> 00:52:46.400
Now these guys you can just
keep them as servers as well.

1010
00:52:46.400 --> 00:52:51.210
The problem with keeping these guys as
servers is someone can come over here and

1011
00:52:51.210 --> 00:52:55.130
admin, he's out here, he creates a new
VLAN here, gets a new VLAN database.

1012
00:52:55.130 --> 00:52:55.660
What's it do?

1013
00:52:55.660 --> 00:52:56.830
It's got a new number.

1014
00:52:56.830 --> 00:52:58.860
It's gonna update the server here.

1015
00:52:58.860 --> 00:53:00.670
And it's gonna propagate
to all the other ones.

1016
00:53:00.670 --> 00:53:03.540
Now we just change our VLAN database
throughout the entire network.

1017
00:53:03.540 --> 00:53:07.940
So that's how we verify spanning tree,
show spanning tree, find your root bridge.

1018
00:53:07.940 --> 00:53:08.890
Very big objective there.

1019
00:53:08.890 --> 00:53:09.490
When we come back,

1020
00:53:09.490 --> 00:53:12.550
we have another objective all right based
on this,on this virtual trunk protocol and

1021
00:53:12.550 --> 00:53:14.970
we're gonna move on to ether channel and
so on.

1022
00:53:14.970 --> 00:53:17.140
But remember, show spanning tree.

1023
00:53:18.690 --> 00:53:21.270
>> Alright, so in this segment,
remember that what we took a look at here,

1024
00:53:21.270 --> 00:53:25.040
of course is the basics of spanning
tree and getting that understanding,

1025
00:53:25.040 --> 00:53:26.820
that foundational knowledge that we need.

1026
00:53:26.820 --> 00:53:28.420
To get ready for that exam.

1027
00:53:28.420 --> 00:53:32.460
You do not want to head into that exam if
you do not know this process of being able

1028
00:53:32.460 --> 00:53:35.290
to find out the different
components that Todd talked about.

1029
00:53:35.290 --> 00:53:38.280
Such as a root bridge, knowing how
to also discover the root port,

1030
00:53:38.280 --> 00:53:40.910
as well as what ports will be
on forwarding, or blocking, or

1031
00:53:40.910 --> 00:53:44.680
the idea here of the discarding as well.

1032
00:53:44.680 --> 00:53:47.780
Go back and take a look at this episode
a couple of times as you get ready for

1033
00:53:47.780 --> 00:53:49.120
that exam.

1034
00:53:49.120 --> 00:53:51.290
Well, that's a great place for
us to go ahead and sign off.

1035
00:53:51.290 --> 00:53:54.440
Signing off for IT Pro TV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

1036

>> And Tom Lammle.

1037

switching content.

00:54:01.695 --> 00:54:07.360

episodes.description: In this episode, Mr. Lammle continues with demonstrating how to verify and change how spanning tree protocol can work by manually changing the priority to become the root bridge and by configuring a switch to become the root for a particular vlan.  Todd also describes the use of VTP and it’s practical usage by configuring the VTP domain-name and mode.  Even so it can be practical, it’s considered to bring more problems than solutions to a switching network.
episodes.title: Enhanced Switching Part 2

00:00:57.153 --> 00:01:03.685
All right, so virtual trunk protocol, or

VTP, allows me to create a VLAN

00:02:33.772 --> 00:02:38.362
Everyone deletes their VLAN database and

episodes.description: In this episode, Cisco Expert, Todd Lammle demonstrates and explains the configuration and use of EtherChannel.  He discusses bundling multiple links together to provide redundancy and more bandwidth between switches.  In STP, the entire EtherChannel is seen as a single logical link.  There are 2 configuration:  PAgP and LACP.  They must be configured on both sides of the connection with a port-group, interfaces must be added to a channel-group.

episodes.description: In this episode, Mr. Todd Lammle introduces the routing protocol of OSPF.   OSPF is a link-state protocol that uses the Shortest Path First Algorithm to determine the best route to the destination and does more, according to Todd.  He tells us that OSPF also creates a neighbor table, topology table and routing table based on “cost” (bandwidth).  OSPF doesn’t exchange routes so much as link-states between routers, Todd says.  He also describes that routers can report different LSAs depending on whether the router is an ABR, Area Border Router or ASBR, Autonomous System Border Router.  He also shows the basic OSPF configuration styles using the ‘Router OSPF <Process-ID>’ command or per interface using ‘ip ospf <proccess-id> area<area-id>1’
episodes.title: OSPF

episodes.description: In this episode, Cisco Expert Todd Lammle continues to describe and demonstrates how routers become OSPF neighbors and what fields must match for routers to become neighbors.  He describes how, from where and when the different LSA are advertised out.  If your OSPF is in ethernet broadcast network, OSPF will elect a DR, Designated Router and a BDR, Backup Designated Router.  He shows the basic configuration and verification of OSPF single area and multiple area configuration.
episodes.title: OSPF Part 2

I can have different over here, pretty

All right so OSPF uses hello packets,

These provide dynamic neighbor discovery,

We had non-broadcast

And that doesn't happen

125
00:06:15.900 --> 00:06:17.710
So we won't see these elections.

00:06:21.550 --> 00:06:25.220

00:06:25.220 --> 00:06:28.392

129
00:06:28.392 --> 00:06:30.520

It helped us work in really large internet

We could add new routers, right.

Whoever has the highest RID would

The point is that whoever
has the highest RID

if they start up at the exact time, right?

So if this guy starts out before

And this guy comes up and

142

This guy comes in and
says but I got a higher RID.

143
00:07:10.140 --> 00:07:11.100
Doesn't matter.

144

So, it's cumbersome to do this.

This is why a lot pf people went out and

00:07:19.800 --> 00:07:23.210
Right, so

So, if I create a little

every router,
I'd have to do 172 16 30.0/24.

00:07:42.100 --> 00:07:45.960
Well, I couldn't put
anything in the 30 something

it somewhere else it would get
duplicate RID Issues, right?

156

That's another troubleshooting

Duplicate RIDs, that is an objective.

So hold on to that thought.

Now so what we do is we're gonna go

this is a relatively new configuration,

based on how old OSPF is.

This is the way to do your rets.

So, first off,
I'm just gonna create a sub.

And let's say I had 100 routers.

165

I don't know, that's not a lot.

166
00:08:18.400 --> 00:08:20.160
Let's say I had 100 routers.

I can just do a slash 24 network, right?

Which is 172, 16, 172,
31, 1.0 network, right?

169
00:08:25.720 --> 00:08:28.150
And then I need the routers .1,
.2, .3, .4.

170

When I put it under here,
there are each individual slash 32s,

so I can put it under a loop back as
a slash 32, or I can use this process ID.

172

Entities, concepts and OSPF 3, or OSPF

1088
00:55:24.530 --> 00:55:28.160
version 2 I think is what the IP version
>> V2.

1089
00:55:28.160 --> 00:55:31.530
>> Yeah, V2, when we start seeing that,

1090
00:55:31.530 --> 00:55:35.990
if any of this doesn't sound great make
sure you check Todd's book out as well.

1091
00:55:35.990 --> 00:55:39.370
So that's a great place for us to end
this episode like I was saying here.

1092
00:55:39.370 --> 00:55:42.860
And signing off for ITPro TV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

1093
00:55:42.860 --> 00:55:43.960
>> And Todd Lammle.

1094
00:55:43.960 --> 00:55:51.153
>> Stay tuned right here for
more CCNA Routing and Switching content.

1095
00:55:51.153 --> 00:55:54.381
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd Lammle introduces EIGRP as a routing protocol.  This protocol creates a 100% loop free routing for all routers configured with EIGRP.  He also describes how EIGRP builds a neighbor table, topology table and routing table to discover not only the best route (Successor) but also the next best route (Feasible Successor).  Todd also shows the simple configuration for EIGRP and differences for using subnets depending on the IOS version.  To insure that routers become EIGRP neighbors, routers must match on Autonomous System number and K-Values, Todd reminds us.
episodes.title: EIGRP
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.043 --> 00:00:10.043
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.262 --> 00:00:13.320
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.860 --> 00:00:17.460
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and today,

4
00:00:17.460 --> 00:00:22.010
we're taking a look at ICND2 content,
getting ready for that CCNA routing and

5
00:00:22.010 --> 00:00:24.340
switching exam that
Cisco has just released.

6
00:00:24.340 --> 00:00:26.870
In our studio today is gonna be Mr.
Todd Lammle,

7
00:00:26.870 --> 00:00:31.250
who's gonna help us to ensure that we are
focused in on those exam objectives, so

8
00:00:31.250 --> 00:00:32.400
welcome back to our studios, Todd.

9
00:00:32.400 --> 00:00:34.500
>> All right, it's great to be here.

10
00:00:34.500 --> 00:00:36.170
Let's jump right into routing protocols.

11
00:00:36.170 --> 00:00:39.500
We're gonna do EIGRP,
OSPF and then multiarea OSPF.

12

At the very end when we get to WANs,
we're gonna add in BGP in this new ICND2.

13
00:00:44.902 --> 00:00:47.359
So let's start with EIGRP,
let's take a look.

14
00:00:47.359 --> 00:00:51.315
Okay, so EIGRP stands for Enhanced
Interior Gateway Routing Protocol,

15
00:00:51.315 --> 00:00:53.660
also we used to have just IGRP.

16
00:00:53.660 --> 00:00:55.950
So EIGRP is advanced distance vector.

17
00:00:57.060 --> 00:01:02.632
Also, maybe some people call it a hybrid,
but advanced distance vector.

18
00:01:02.632 --> 00:01:05.614
It's the most rapid convergence
of any routing protocol.

19
00:01:05.614 --> 00:01:09.016
So in OSPF would be faster than RIP,
stuff like that.

20
00:01:09.016 --> 00:01:13.148
100% loop free, classless routing,
that's a pretty bold statement.

21
00:01:13.148 --> 00:01:16.379
And the reason they say that,
as we're gonna find out next slide,

22
00:01:16.379 --> 00:01:18.178
that we make three tables, not one.

23
00:01:18.178 --> 00:01:20.565
Like in RIP, they have one table,
one routing table, and

24
00:01:20.565 --> 00:01:21.850
they share that information.

25
00:01:21.850 --> 00:01:25.220
We don't share routing table information,
we'll take a look here.

26
00:01:25.220 --> 00:01:30.380
The one thing is though,
we have a complexity of a routing

27
00:01:30.380 --> 00:01:35.470
protocol like OSPF, in the background, but
with the ease of configuration of RIP.

28
00:01:35.470 --> 00:01:38.800
OSPF is hard to configure, and
it works hard in the background, right?

29
00:01:38.800 --> 00:01:41.880
Everything about OSPF is hard,
with EIGRP, it's very simple.

30
00:01:41.880 --> 00:01:44.850
So what Cisco says, is hey,
we're gonna come up with this

31
00:01:44.850 --> 00:01:47.000
phenomenal routing protocol,
that does all this work in the background.

32
00:01:47.000 --> 00:01:47.970
Don't worry about that.

33
00:01:47.970 --> 00:01:51.430
Configure it like you were doing RIP and
let EIGRP do the work.

34
00:01:51.430 --> 00:01:53.570
And that is a very true statement.

35
00:01:53.570 --> 00:01:58.600
Okay, so easy configuration,
incremental updates instead of periodic.

36
00:01:58.600 --> 00:02:05.330
So RIP sends periodic updates,
right, of its

37
00:02:05.330 --> 00:02:10.490
routing table every 30 seconds, right, and
so we don't send any updates ever, right.

38
00:02:11.720 --> 00:02:16.690
So anyways, load balancing across
equal and unequal cost pathways.

39
00:02:18.570 --> 00:02:23.400
So unlike other routing protocols,
which they all do equal cost paths,

40
00:02:23.400 --> 00:02:27.410
we can configure this, and
we will to do unequal cost paths.

41
00:02:27.410 --> 00:02:31.880
In my lab, I have two serial links between
San Francisco and LA, and we'll be able to

42
00:02:31.880 --> 00:02:35.370
use those and put a variance in there and
make them unequal, it'll be fun.

43
00:02:35.370 --> 00:02:37.850
All right, flexible network design,
that's right.

44
00:02:39.230 --> 00:02:40.080
Configuration of OSPF,

45
00:02:40.080 --> 00:02:44.120
it has to be done in a really good
designed network or OSPF doesn't converge.

46
00:02:44.120 --> 00:02:46.210
EIGRP will work in any
crappy network design.

47
00:02:46.210 --> 00:02:48.430
You just turn them on, it'll find a way.

48
00:02:48.430 --> 00:02:50.870
OSPF won't do that, all right.

49
00:02:50.870 --> 00:02:53.150
Multicast is all we use.

50
00:02:53.150 --> 00:02:57.600
And then sometimes with something
called reliable transport protocol,

51
00:02:57.600 --> 00:02:59.498
we'll be able to talk to our neighbor and
use unicast.

52
00:02:59.498 --> 00:03:02.780
Unicast may not know its IP address,
I'm gonna talk to it directly.

53
00:03:02.780 --> 00:03:06.225
All right, support for
VLSM and discontiguous,

54
00:03:06.225 --> 00:03:09.842
networks by doing the No Auto,
like we did with RIP.

55
00:03:09.842 --> 00:03:13.159
So but we have to talk about that in
a little bit more detail on this,

56
00:03:13.159 --> 00:03:14.300
on the 15 code here.

57
00:03:14.300 --> 00:03:16.531
And then, of course,
we can do route summarization.

58
00:03:20.247 --> 00:03:25.168
Okay, so with EIGRP terminology,
we have three tables.

59
00:03:25.168 --> 00:03:31.052
So when we come up, we do this 224.0.0.10.

60
00:03:31.052 --> 00:03:33.951
Does anyone remember
what RIP Version 2 was?

61
00:03:33.951 --> 00:03:35.468
224.0.0.

62
00:03:35.468 --> 00:03:37.710
>> Nine?
>> Nine is the correct answer.

63
00:03:37.710 --> 00:03:41.061
You do need to know these numbers, and

64
00:03:41.061 --> 00:03:45.262
they're gonna be good for
IPV6 too, as well.

65
00:03:45.262 --> 00:03:49.233
Anyways, so 224.0.0.10,
you're like, no we can't use 224,

66
00:03:49.233 --> 00:03:53.105
that's not what I am saying, we'll
use those 9 and 10 with IP Version 6.

67
00:03:53.105 --> 00:03:56.725
All right, 224.0.0.10 with IP Version 4,

68
00:03:56.725 --> 00:04:02.279
the neighbor table we come up, we find out
who's our neighbor, we put them in there.

69
00:04:02.279 --> 00:04:05.502
We're gonna find we run something
called a smooth round-trip time.

70
00:04:05.502 --> 00:04:07.425
How many milliseconds for
me to get my neighbor and back?

71
00:04:07.425 --> 00:04:09.110
And then they do it to us.

72
00:04:09.110 --> 00:04:11.489
And it helps us determine
the bandwidth and delay of the line or

73
00:04:11.489 --> 00:04:13.340
the delay between me and my neighbor.

74
00:04:13.340 --> 00:04:15.530
Anyway, so we've put in the next hop.

75
00:04:15.530 --> 00:04:18.754
Int router in the interface they're
off of, we know their IP address,

76
00:04:18.754 --> 00:04:22.212
the interface they're off of, and
the delay that a time takes to get there.

77
00:04:22.212 --> 00:04:25.270
All right, then we go, and
we talk to our neighbor.

78
00:04:26.630 --> 00:04:29.090
We go and talk to our neighbor, and

79
00:04:29.090 --> 00:04:32.810
we say, I need to know about everything,
all the links you know about.

80
00:04:32.810 --> 00:04:34.690
What are all the links you're
directly connected to?

81
00:04:34.690 --> 00:04:36.616
Okay, I'm gonna put those
in my topology table.

82
00:04:36.616 --> 00:04:37.844
I'm gonna put all mine in there.

83
00:04:37.844 --> 00:04:40.573
I'm gonna put my neighbors in there,
I talked to all of my neighbors.

84
00:04:40.573 --> 00:04:42.067
And then I'm gonna go to them and say,

85
00:04:42.067 --> 00:04:44.795
tell me about all the other links
you're not directly connected to.

86
00:04:44.795 --> 00:04:46.863
And I'm gonna put those
in my typology table,

87
00:04:46.863 --> 00:04:49.270
I'm gonna add my cost to my neighbor.

88
00:04:49.270 --> 00:04:51.935
And then that's what's called a feasible
distance, don't get confused,

89
00:04:51.935 --> 00:04:53.949
we'll come back to that,
jumping ahead with some terms.

90
00:04:53.949 --> 00:04:57.480
I know you're like, I'm gonna turn this
off, he's doing all these terms already.

91
00:04:57.480 --> 00:05:02.500
[LAUGH] I'm just trying to make sure that
you understand that we have three tables.

92
00:05:02.500 --> 00:05:04.800
We have three with OSPF too, but
they're a little bit different.

93
00:05:04.800 --> 00:05:06.035
We have the neighbor table here,

94
00:05:06.035 --> 00:05:09.660
topology table,
now we find every link in the network.

95
00:05:09.660 --> 00:05:14.510
If we have more than one path to remote
network, we're gonna run something

96
00:05:14.510 --> 00:05:19.960
called DUAL diffused update algorithm.

97
00:05:19.960 --> 00:05:24.170
You'll actually see what you find here,
in the routing table with a D,

98
00:05:24.170 --> 00:05:25.590
which stands for DUAL.

99
00:05:25.590 --> 00:05:29.782
Because DUAL found it, pulls it out,
finds the best path, and that best path is

100
00:05:29.782 --> 00:05:33.789
called a successor path, pulls it out,
places it in the routing table, and

101
00:05:33.789 --> 00:05:37.132
the only thing in the routing
table is this successful routes.

102
00:05:37.132 --> 00:05:38.810
We only want winners.

103
00:05:38.810 --> 00:05:41.040
No losers in our routing table.

104
00:05:41.040 --> 00:05:43.625
The losers now are still
in topology table, and

105
00:05:43.625 --> 00:05:46.050
they're considered backup routes.

106
00:05:46.050 --> 00:05:48.396
Okay, we call them feasible successors.

107
00:05:48.396 --> 00:05:52.461
So the successors are the best path
of remote location, we copy those,

108
00:05:52.461 --> 00:05:53.900
we don't pull them out.

109
00:05:53.900 --> 00:05:56.972
You don't pull them out of topology,
you copy them,

110
00:05:56.972 --> 00:06:01.102
place them into the routing table,
and those are my successor routes.

111
00:06:01.102 --> 00:06:05.540
Now IP can use that to forward
traffic to a destination.

112
00:06:07.600 --> 00:06:11.180
Now, so DUAL finds the best path.

113
00:06:11.180 --> 00:06:15.298
Now Ronnie, by default,
if I didn't do anything, how many paths,

114
00:06:15.298 --> 00:06:18.355
do you think,
equal cost paths can I have in there?

115
00:06:18.355 --> 00:06:20.340
>> Up to 4 or 16.

116
00:06:20.340 --> 00:06:21.787
>> Well, it is four by default.

117
00:06:21.787 --> 00:06:22.465
>> Four by default.

118
00:06:22.465 --> 00:06:25.674
>> And I think if we go look here, it can
probably be configured to 32 now, but

119
00:06:25.674 --> 00:06:27.647
well, it depends on
the code we're running.

120
00:06:27.647 --> 00:06:28.677
>> Right.

121
00:06:28.677 --> 00:06:30.938
>> So 16 is really the answer.

122
00:06:30.938 --> 00:06:33.386
I don't think they even
ask this on the CCNA, but

123
00:06:33.386 --> 00:06:35.690
it is four equal cost paths by default.

124
00:06:35.690 --> 00:06:39.260
What we're gonna do is we're gonna see
that in our routing configuration,

125
00:06:39.260 --> 00:06:41.260
cuz I have that other link up and running.

126
00:06:41.260 --> 00:06:42.110
So we'll make sure, and

127
00:06:42.110 --> 00:06:44.390
we'll see that it'll load
balance cuz it'll be equal cost.

128
00:06:44.390 --> 00:06:46.140
Then we'll change that.

129
00:06:46.140 --> 00:06:48.420
But in the meantime,
we'll let it go out and find it,

130
00:06:48.420 --> 00:06:51.030
and we'll see that our little RIP network
found it as well, cuz RIP is still running

131
00:06:51.030 --> 00:06:53.890
in the background,
way back then when we were doing CSEnt.

132
00:06:53.890 --> 00:06:56.620
All right, so successor,
feasible successor,

133
00:06:56.620 --> 00:07:01.360
DUAL, we talked about a bunch of terms,
feasible distance and so on.

134
00:07:01.360 --> 00:07:04.260
All right, now in the EIGRP tables,

135
00:07:04.260 --> 00:07:07.090
we have the neighbor table and
the topology table.

136
00:07:07.090 --> 00:07:11.993
Now remember, we do not exchange routing
table information with our neighbors

137
00:07:11.993 --> 00:07:12.952
like RIP does.

138
00:07:12.952 --> 00:07:17.058
We talk to our neighbors and
exchange neighbor information but

139
00:07:17.058 --> 00:07:18.691
topology information.

140
00:07:18.691 --> 00:07:21.484
We don't update the routing
table based on the neighbor,

141
00:07:21.484 --> 00:07:23.200
we base it from our topology table.

142
00:07:23.200 --> 00:07:24.590
So let's go back for a second.

143
00:07:24.590 --> 00:07:28.680
So if I'm here, this gets updated,
this then updates the routing table.

144
00:07:28.680 --> 00:07:31.203
My neighbor doesn't update my
routing table, that's RIP, right?

145
00:07:31.203 --> 00:07:33.220
Even OSPF doesn't do that.

146
00:07:33.220 --> 00:07:37.960
In OSPF, we update topological database,
in this case our topology table.

147
00:07:37.960 --> 00:07:40.300
That gets updated by our neighbors, right?

148
00:07:40.300 --> 00:07:43.420
This is what we use to communicate
with our neighbors, to update those.

149
00:07:43.420 --> 00:07:47.230
And we only have the best answer
provided into the routing table.

150
00:07:47.230 --> 00:07:49.520
Only winners, winners.

151
00:07:49.520 --> 00:07:52.880
All right, so that neighbor table
in topology are kept in RAM.

152
00:07:52.880 --> 00:07:56.306
Well, the routing table's there too,
but it's not up-to-date or

153
00:07:56.306 --> 00:07:58.816
maintained to the use of hello and
update packets.

154
00:07:58.816 --> 00:08:02.552
So with hello and
update packets between me and my neighbor,

155
00:08:02.552 --> 00:08:05.495
I update my neighbor table and
topology table.

156
00:08:05.495 --> 00:08:08.011
From there I'll update my routing table.

157
00:08:08.011 --> 00:08:16.081
All right, so to enhance the EIGRP
224.0.0.10, do you know how often?

158
00:08:16.081 --> 00:08:18.345
Every five seconds.

159
00:08:18.345 --> 00:08:19.065
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

160
00:08:19.065 --> 00:08:20.040
>> Every five seconds, so

161
00:08:20.040 --> 00:08:21.874
I'm gonna send a hello every five seconds.

162
00:08:21.874 --> 00:08:25.280
With OSPF it's every 10 seconds,
cuz they do something similar to this.

163
00:08:25.280 --> 00:08:26.810
Not exactly like this.

164
00:08:26.810 --> 00:08:32.170
But similar because with EIGRP and
OSPF we never send updates, right?

165
00:08:32.170 --> 00:08:35.770
So, if we never send updates,
how do we know if a change occurs?

166
00:08:35.770 --> 00:08:37.320
Well that's why we send the hellos.

167
00:08:37.320 --> 00:08:39.990
If our neighbor stops responding we're
like, something must have happened,

168
00:08:39.990 --> 00:08:41.508
let's figure it out.

169
00:08:41.508 --> 00:08:44.850
Okay, so EIGRP Keeps everything in RAM,

170
00:08:44.850 --> 00:08:48.350
so if I reload my router,
we have to redo all this.

171
00:08:48.350 --> 00:08:52.100
So we may not wanna just reload or reboot
our router every time something happens.

172
00:08:52.100 --> 00:08:55.840
You know, the three R's that Microsoft
taught us, reload, reboot, reset?

173
00:08:55.840 --> 00:08:58.300
>> Right. [LAUGH] >> Right,
whatever, reset, reload, reboot.

174
00:08:58.300 --> 00:09:00.890
Right, that's what Microsoft said there
was a problem, due to the three R's.

175
00:09:00.890 --> 00:09:02.010
That's not so anymore, right?

176
00:09:02.010 --> 00:09:04.040
We don't wanna do that with our Cisco.

177
00:09:04.040 --> 00:09:05.560
Successor routes.

178
00:09:05.560 --> 00:09:07.430
Okay, and I already talked about these.

179
00:09:07.430 --> 00:09:11.140
Successor routes are in
the topology table.

180
00:09:11.140 --> 00:09:13.950
You do not pull anything
out of the topology table.

181
00:09:13.950 --> 00:09:18.430
You copy something out of the topology
table and put it into your routing table.

182
00:09:18.430 --> 00:09:21.860
So this is copied out and
put into the routing table.

183
00:09:21.860 --> 00:09:24.490
So, who decided what do we use,

184
00:09:24.490 --> 00:09:28.010
what algorithm did we use to determine
who was successor and feasible successor?

185
00:09:28.010 --> 00:09:28.660
>> Dual.

186
00:09:28.660 --> 00:09:30.410
>> Dual is the correct answer.

187
00:09:30.410 --> 00:09:31.460
Diffused update algorithm.

188
00:09:31.460 --> 00:09:33.460
If found the best path,
found the other one,

189
00:09:33.460 --> 00:09:35.550
this guy's a loser, this guy's a winner.

190
00:09:35.550 --> 00:09:37.040
He goes into the routing table.

191
00:09:37.040 --> 00:09:40.290
We'll use him if we have no other choice,
right?

192
00:09:40.290 --> 00:09:44.070
All right, a successor route may be backed
up by feasible successor, and remember,

193
00:09:44.070 --> 00:09:48.710
successor routes are both in the topology
table and in the routing table.

194
00:09:48.710 --> 00:09:51.530
Now if I lose a route and
there's no feasible successor,

195
00:09:51.530 --> 00:09:52.840
I'm gonna send a query.

196
00:09:52.840 --> 00:09:58.030
So EIGRP is a distance
vector advanced protocol.

197
00:09:58.030 --> 00:09:59.780
So part of its DV,

198
00:09:59.780 --> 00:10:02.970
distance vector qualities is we're
gonna flood the network, all right?

199
00:10:02.970 --> 00:10:05.080
So when we have a problem,
we're gonna query process.

200
00:10:05.080 --> 00:10:08.950
It's used to discover a replacement for
a failed route

201
00:10:08.950 --> 00:10:13.290
Failed route if a feasible successor
is not identified in the current.

202
00:10:13.290 --> 00:10:16.720
So we're gonna actually
flood our current network

203
00:10:16.720 --> 00:10:20.030
if we don't find a feasible successor,
looking for it.

204
00:10:20.030 --> 00:10:24.260
So we don't wait,
we are proactive with the IGRP.

205
00:10:24.260 --> 00:10:25.470
And that's why we're so fast, and

206
00:10:25.470 --> 00:10:27.300
that's part of its distance
vector qualities right there.

207
00:10:28.520 --> 00:10:33.170
Okay, so let's get to the easy part of all
this, and then there's still a little more

208
00:10:33.170 --> 00:10:35.260
complication in the background
we have to go over.

209
00:10:35.260 --> 00:10:38.360
And then we're going to configure,
and verify, and do IPN, and IPV6.

210
00:10:38.360 --> 00:10:41.730
But nonetheless,
to configure EIGRP is really easy.

211
00:10:41.730 --> 00:10:46.530
We say router EIGRP and we make up
a number between one and 65,353.

212
00:10:46.530 --> 00:10:50.630
Okay, so we make up a number,
doesn't matter what number it is.

213
00:10:50.630 --> 00:10:54.850
However, every router that you
want to share information with

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd Lammle demonstrates troubleshooting skills on Cisco routers.  He implements multiple routing protocols including RIP,RIPng, EIGRP, OSPF and OSPF v3 on points out the troubleshooting points to examine when routing isn’t occurring.  He also points out issues with using default-information originate.

episodes.description: In this episode, Cisco Expert Todd Lammle continues with troubleshooting with EIGRP in IPv6 and makes sure we understand the configuration issue of typing no shutdown in the ipv6 router configuration.  He also goes into details about neighbor adjacencies not forming and shows how to compare the configurations for the matching values we must see. He also assigns an access-list to a routing protocol and well as demonstrates access-list application. He turns his attention to switches and demonstrates using SPAN and SLA testing to round out the list of tools that we can use to help troubleshooting routing and switching on cisco devices.

episodes.description: In this episode, Cisco Expert, Todd Lammle describes some of the Wide Area Network technologies such as leased, shared and broadband connections between sites.  He then describes and configures PPP and Multi-Link PPP connections between routers and demonstrates how to configure a dialer configuration.
episodes.title: Wide Area Networks

00:07:54.424 --> 00:07:56.125
If you have two Cisco routers,

00:07:56.125 --> 00:07:57.865
Here's what's awesome about it.

00:07:57.865 --> 00:07:59.171
It's featureless.

00:07:59.171 --> 00:08:00.175
It does nothing.

00:08:00.175 --> 00:08:03.760
There's no, it's connection oriented,

HDLC is featureless,
which makes it awesome, all right.

00:08:40.055 --> 00:08:44.235
It's clean, it's fast, right,
now, but it's proprietary, right.

00:08:44.235 --> 00:08:47.285
But every vendor has it, so
if you have two other Junipers or

Now that being said, if I have two,
a Cisco and a non-Cisco, or typically,

176
00:08:59.200 --> 00:09:03.330
All right, so I'm gonna go ahead and
run NCP runs and allows me,

It allows me to have multiple
routed protocols, IP, IPv6,

179
00:09:09.680 --> 00:09:12.196

180
00:09:12.196 --> 00:09:14.400
So HDLC is proprietary.

181

episodes.description: In this episode, Mr. Todd Lammle describes VPN technologies.  He categories them into Enterprise-Managed VPN and Service Provider VPNs.  Then he describes the most common types of Enterprise-Managed VPNs such as remote access, site-to-site and extranet vpns.  Todd also describes and configures a GRE tunnel and BGP.
episodes.title: Wide Area Networks Part 2

It comes out of the VPN concentrator,

Whoops.

Let's go ahead and go ahead and

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd introduces us to HSRP and GLBP.  HSRP has reappeared as an exam objective even though rarely used in production systems; the standard today will be GLBP, according to Lammle.  He configures HSRP as a fault tolerant system to take over, using the standby command and preempt will allow us to configure this configuration and create a virtual router with a virtual IP address.

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.038 --> 00:00:10.038
[MUSIC]

2

Welcome to another exciting
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.438 --> 00:00:19.670
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and
today we're taking that ICND2 content,

4
00:00:19.670 --> 00:00:22.905
getting ready for
that CCNA routing and switching exam.

5
00:00:22.905 --> 00:00:26.865
To help us to prepare for that, we have
Mr. Todd Lammie here in our studios.

6
00:00:26.865 --> 00:00:28.127
Welcome back to our studios.

7
00:00:28.127 --> 00:00:29.434
>> All right thanks, great to be here.

8
00:00:29.434 --> 00:00:32.992
Let's finish up with our last installment
of the enhanced switching sections.

9
00:00:32.992 --> 00:00:36.136
This is called first hop
redundancy protocols.

10
00:00:36.136 --> 00:00:37.653
Let's go ahead and take a look.

11
00:00:37.653 --> 00:00:41.463
But I got some good news as we dive
into this guys, the first thing is,

12
00:00:41.463 --> 00:00:44.976
before we dive in,
we're only gonna cover one protocol here.

13
00:00:44.976 --> 00:00:47.396
Now I don't really necessarily
like what they did.

14
00:00:47.396 --> 00:00:50.262
You're gonna like it if you're
studying for exam objectives, but for

15
00:00:50.262 --> 00:00:51.466
real life it's not so great.

16
00:00:51.466 --> 00:00:55.811
We're gonna only cover
something called HSRP.

17
00:00:55.811 --> 00:00:58.679
They took out what you should use today,
GLBP,

18
00:00:58.679 --> 00:01:03.425
gateway load balancing protocol,
that's the much, much better protocol.

19
00:01:03.425 --> 00:01:05.834
And they're only using
the really old HSRP, but

20
00:01:05.834 --> 00:01:07.550
let's take a look at what that is.

21
00:01:07.550 --> 00:01:08.652
So if you're studying for

22
00:01:08.652 --> 00:01:12.258
your exam objective, this is a very short
section, so you're happy about that, but

23
00:01:12.258 --> 00:01:15.030
you're not happy about not learning
what you use in production.

24
00:01:15.030 --> 00:01:18.595
All right, that being said, so I have a,
here's the problem with IP version 4,

25
00:01:18.595 --> 00:01:20.611
I think as I've gotten
too over the past week,

26
00:01:20.611 --> 00:01:23.318
I think you've all realized that
I think IP version 4 sucks.

27
00:01:23.318 --> 00:01:24.720
It really does.

28
00:01:24.720 --> 00:01:29.738
For example, you can only put one default
gateway on a host, that's ridiculous.

29
00:01:29.738 --> 00:01:31.972
You've only always been able to do that.

30
00:01:31.972 --> 00:01:36.053
So what they did is they came
up with something first, a long,

31
00:01:36.053 --> 00:01:39.830
long time ago, before HSRP,
that was called proxy arp.

32
00:01:39.830 --> 00:01:45.212
Now, proxy arp enabled hosts,
with no knowledge that says of routers,

33
00:01:45.212 --> 00:01:49.992
router options to obtain the mac
address of the gateway, okay.

34
00:01:49.992 --> 00:01:56.252
So, basically what that allowed us to
do was to just go ahead and arp for it.

35
00:01:56.252 --> 00:01:57.497
So, what we use to do, and

36
00:01:57.497 --> 00:02:01.208
you don't do this anymore, is you
wouldn't set a default gateway on a host.

37
00:02:01.208 --> 00:02:05.020
So any time you go say,
to an IP address on a remote network,

38
00:02:05.020 --> 00:02:07.476
it would just arp for that IP address.

39
00:02:07.476 --> 00:02:11.082
The routers, CISCO routers,
on their interfaces, and

40
00:02:11.082 --> 00:02:13.945
you can see this with
the shell IP interface.

41
00:02:13.945 --> 00:02:17.700
You can see that proxy arp is enabled on
all CISCO routers by default, that means

42
00:02:17.700 --> 00:02:21.693
it responds to all arp requests for remote
network and says, I'm that host, rght.

43
00:02:21.693 --> 00:02:26.287
And what that did is it created just
a tremendous amount of traffic, right, so

44
00:02:26.287 --> 00:02:31.317
that was a solution, but albeit with IP
version four again, another poor solution.

45
00:02:31.317 --> 00:02:33.198
Right, then they came up with HSRP.

46
00:02:33.198 --> 00:02:37.344
This is an okay solution, the better
one was GLBP that Cisco came up with.

47
00:02:37.344 --> 00:02:40.680
HSRP, Cisco proprietary
GLBP Cisco proprietary,

48
00:02:40.680 --> 00:02:44.639
GLBP though did load balancing across,
where HSRP does not.

49
00:02:44.639 --> 00:02:48.380
We'll talk about its load balancing
capabilities, or lack of, but

50
00:02:48.380 --> 00:02:52.377
there was also something called VRRP,
which was in the last objectives,

51
00:02:52.377 --> 00:02:55.619
which is a non proprietary
first hop redundancy protocol.

52
00:02:55.619 --> 00:02:59.785
So all you have to study is HSRP,
one command and you're done.

53
00:02:59.785 --> 00:03:02.006
>> [LAUGH]
>> So this is a very short section.

54
00:03:02.006 --> 00:03:05.012
All right, so in this case here,
if we had a default gateway configured and

55
00:03:05.012 --> 00:03:06.172
it went down, we were done.

56
00:03:06.172 --> 00:03:09.812
So basically, what it did is,
we said, okay, we come over here,

57
00:03:09.812 --> 00:03:12.672
we're gonna have what's
called a virtual router.

58
00:03:12.672 --> 00:03:16.421
So basically, we have a virtual IP
address, virtual MAC address, that

59
00:03:16.421 --> 00:03:20.538
responds to the host The host is talking
to this one router or one virtual address

60
00:03:20.538 --> 00:03:24.555
the entire time and it doesn't matter
if one router goes down like over here.

61
00:03:24.555 --> 00:03:27.553
Then this router just
starts responding okay.

62
00:03:27.553 --> 00:03:31.079
So basically it allows us
to have a redundancy, and

63
00:03:31.079 --> 00:03:33.135
you can have up to 8 routers.

64
00:03:33.135 --> 00:03:38.656
One's active one's standby and the other
ones backup routers aren't doing anything.

65
00:03:38.656 --> 00:03:40.952
So, CISCO would love it if you did that,
right, for

66
00:03:40.952 --> 00:03:43.841
every LAN you had eight standby,
eight backup routers, right.

67
00:03:43.841 --> 00:03:47.501
So, at a minimum,
this gave us some redundancy, though.

68
00:03:47.501 --> 00:03:52.462
Now, so HSRP defines a group of routers,
one active and one standby,

69
00:03:52.462 --> 00:03:54.913
all right, and then one virtual.

70
00:03:54.913 --> 00:03:58.539
So, literally, they ask you in the
objectives, what are the three modes, and

71
00:03:58.539 --> 00:04:02.022
this isn't necessarily true, but
it's active, standby, and virtual.

72
00:04:02.022 --> 00:04:07.124
But just remember that, so
HSRP defines groups of routers.

73
00:04:07.124 --> 00:04:10.458
Now, [COUGH] so virtual IP and
virtual MAC addresses are shared,

74
00:04:10.458 --> 00:04:13.187
and there's something I
wanna share with you here.

75
00:04:13.187 --> 00:04:16.435
And I'm gonna show you that
the virtual MAC address,

76
00:04:16.435 --> 00:04:20.273
you need to be able to pick this
out in the objectives for Cisco.

77
00:04:20.273 --> 00:04:23.461
So you got your vendor, so this is
a MAC address, and I split it up here.

78
00:04:23.461 --> 00:04:25.576
And then here's the Cisco HSRP.

79
00:04:25.576 --> 00:04:31.069
So what you're gonna look for
is the 07.ac, 07.ac, in the address.

80
00:04:31.069 --> 00:04:34.942
And then you have your HSRP group number,
all right?

81
00:04:34.942 --> 00:04:39.611
So I have to be able to look and see
that's it's a virtual Cisco MAC address.

82
00:04:39.611 --> 00:04:43.943
It's always gonna be Cisco when it's HSRP,
but 07.ac is what we're gonna look for.

83
00:04:43.943 --> 00:04:47.511
Now to understand HSRP there's
just there's just a few things.

84
00:04:47.511 --> 00:04:50.159
I probably get into a little
more detail in book on here.

85
00:04:50.159 --> 00:04:51.871
First off, we have timers.

episodes.description: In this episode, Cisco Expert Todd Lammle helps us to go beyond the concept of just connectivity of cisco devices to the concepts of centralized management and even Software Defined Networking.  Because networks are becoming more complex, we need complex management to allow us to manage network devices regardless of location, or type of device.  Todd explains all these concepts to help us to get ready for the intelligent network.
episodes.title: Evolution of Intelligent Networks
